abstract.p: Preview of Sydney Olympics canoe and kayak races; photo (M)

block.p: THIS SPORT involves men and women in two distinct disciplines: sprint (flat- water) and slalom (whitewater). Two types of craft -- canoes and kayaks -- are used in both. In the canoe, the athlete kneels and uses a single-bladed paddle. In the kayak, the athlete sits and uses a double-bladed paddle.
THE SETUP -- There are 12 events in sprints, four in slalom. Women compete only in kayak. The fiberglass-like canoes and kayaks are as small as 13 feet 1 inch for slalom, 17 feet for sprints.

THIS SPORT involves men and women in two distinct disciplines: sprint (flat- water) and slalom (whitewater). Two types of craft -- canoes and kayaks -- are used in both. In the canoe, the athlete kneels and uses a single-bladed paddle. In the kayak, the athlete sits and uses a double-bladed paddle.
THE SETUP -- There are 12 events in sprints, four in slalom. Women compete only in kayak. The fiberglass-like canoes and kayaks are as small as 13 feet 1 inch for slalom, 17 feet for sprints.

THE SCORING -- With repechage (second-chance) heats no longer used in Olympic sprints, the competition consists of heats, semifinals and finals, all at 500 or 1,000 meters. In slalom, competitors race one at a time through gates and rapids over a course of 300 to 600 meters. Time penalties are assessed for missing or touching a gate. Total time for two runs decides each slalom round.

THE STRATEGY -- Once the slalom course is set, practice runs are barred, so the athletes walk alongside the course to determine how to approach each gate. If they err, they may still survive because they get two runs the first day and the qualifiers get two more the next.

THE NAMES -- Medals choices are headed by Paul Ratcliffe of Britain and Mandy Planert and Suzanne Hirt of Germany in slalom and Martin Doctor of the Czech Republic in canoe sprints. The best Americans are Scott Shipley of Poulsbo, Wash., and Rebecca Bennett-Giddens of Green Bay, Wis., in kayak slalom and 41-year-old David Hearn of Bethesda, Md., in canoe slalom.
